STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Humboldt Creamery is located at 572 Highway 1, Fortuna, California. Humboldt Creamery (Facility) is located at the intersection of State Highway 1 and State Highway 211, and is approximately 3 miles west of Fortuna, California. The site is situated adjacent to the Eel River. 



Anhydrous ammonia is used in a refrigeration system at the Facility. The system provides cooling for ice cream production and finished product storage. Humboldt Creamery utilizes a computerized Refrigeration Control System (RCS) to monitor and control the refrigeration system. The desired temperatures are maintained by controlling the flow of ammonia with manually and electrically operated valves, float switches, transfer pumps, and compressor controls. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Humboldt Creamery prepared the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) / Risk Management Plan (RMP) / Process Safety Management (PSM) program to satisfy regulatory requirements and to demonstrate a commitment to evaluate and improve anhydrous ammonia handling systems and practices at the Facility. Many state-of-the-art safety features were incorporated into the ammonia refrigeration system at the Facility as part of the original system construction and system modifications. In the unlikely event that a chemical release does occur at the Facility, Humboldt Creamery personnel are trained in the appropriate emergency actions to implement and relies on services provided by the local fire department and/or hazardous materials response team. Humboldt Creamery will continue to improve ammonia-handling safety through the implementation of the prevention program elements of the CalARP/RMP/PSM program.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The CalARP/RMP/PSM regulations require a review of the accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps used b

y the Facility. Humboldt Creamery has incorporated many safety features in the ammonia refrigeration system to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is an inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Humboldt Creamery ammonia system is continuously monitored by automated control systems that shut down components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. The major pressure vessels in the system are connected to an Emergency Control Box. To prevent over pressurization, operators can manually equalize pressure of vessels or relieve pressure from the system by discharging vapor at the Emergency Control Box. Ammonia vapor released to control pressure can be directed to the relief header or mixed with water prior to discharge to the lift station. Additionally, pressure vessels in the system are equipped with pressure relief valves at or below the maximum allowable working pressure.

?    Ammonia detection system provides audible and visual alarm signals

?    Additional ammonia detection equipment is installed in the engine room to shut down the system at 2 percent prior to reaching the lower explosive limit of approximately 16 percent

Emergency shutdown and control systems

vated

In addition to the physical features of the ammonia refrigeration system at the Facility, Humboldt Creamery implements administrative controls to maintain safe operation of the system. The CalARP/RMP/PSM prevention program elements implemented by Humboldt Creamery include:

?    Compliance Audits

?    Employee Participation

?    Hot Work Permits

?    Contractor Safety

?    Trade Secrets (none associated with the ammonia refrigeration system)



Humboldt Creamery is committed to maintaining the mechanical integrity of the ammonia refrigeration system. Quarterly meetings are conducted to review and plan system maintenance. Contractor service is scheduled to assist Humboldt Creamery operators in the maintenance of the refrigeration system. Preventive maintenance at the Facility includes daily, weekly, and periodic inspection, testing and maintenance of ammonia system equipment. Additionally, the VaCom monitoring system is used to track equipment performance and to create reports that are used by maintenance personnel to monitor for equipment upsets.

Humboldt Creamery recognizes that the CalARP/RMP/PSM is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its Facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Humboldt Creamery continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. Humboldt Creamery will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the CalARP/RMP/PSM and related attachments and program elements will be incorporated consistent with Humboldt Creamery's internal review practices; Humboldt Creamery will maintain the most current versions onsite. Thus, the most current version CalARP/RMP/PSM and related documents and elements maintained on site may vary slightly from the information submitted to the EPA and other regulatory agencies.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

Humboldt Creamery has developed a written Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that identifies emergency personnel responsibilities, procedures, evacuation measures, notification procedures and reporting requirements. The Humboldt Creamery is a non-responding Facility. Facility personnel will initiate an evacuation and notify offsite responders in the event of an uncontrolled release of ammonia. The Fire Department or Incident Commander will take charge of the emergency response and response team and direct operations when an emergency is declared and will remain in charge until the emergency is ended. Humboldt Creamery is to document coordination of response actions with the local fire department annually. Emergency response actions were last coordinated with the local Loleta Fire Department on December 24, 2019.

The EAP defines incidents that constitute an emergency situation and when offsite emergency response notification is required. The Plant Manager or designee will maintain the EAP. Additionally, a copy of the EAP will be kept with the CalARP/RMP/PSM documentation and at other appropriate locations. Refer to the EAP for further information regarding emergency planning and response.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

Changes to improve safety at the Facility have been ongoing. Humboldt Creamery will respond to suggested mitigation measures promptly. Management responses and support will be consistent with the Facility's commitment to safe and environmentally responsible operations.
